lines.text: Alarums. Enter CASSIUS and TITINIUS

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: O, look, Titinius, look, the villains fly! Myself have to mine own turn'd enemy: This ensign here of mine was turning back; I slew the coward, and did take it from him.

lines.speaker: titinius
lines.text: O Cassius, Brutus gave the word too early; Who, having some advantage on Octavius, Took it too eagerly: his soldiers fell to spoil, Whilst we by Antony are all enclosed.
Enter PINDARUS

lines.speaker: pindarus
lines.text: Fly further off, my lord, fly further off; Mark Antony is in your tents, my lord Fly, therefore, noble Cassius, fly far off.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: This hill is far enough. Look, look, Titinius; Are those my tents where I perceive the fire?

lines.speaker: titinius
lines.text: They are, my lord.

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Titinius, if thou lovest me, Mount thou my horse, and hide thy spurs in him, Till he have brought thee up to yonder troops, And here again; that I may rest assured Whether yond troops are friend or enemy.

lines.speaker: titinius
lines.text: I will be here again, even with a thought.
Exit

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Go, Pindarus, get higher on that hill; My sight was ever thick; regard Titinius, And tell me what thou notest about the field. This day I breathed first: time is come round, And where I did begin, there shall I end; My life is run his compass. Sirrah, what news?
PINDARUS ascends the hill

lines.speaker: pindarus
lines.text: [Above]  O my lord!

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: What news?

lines.speaker: pindarus
lines.text: [Above]  Titinius is enclosed round about With horsemen, that make to him on the spur; Yet he spurs on. Now they are almost on him. Now, Titinius! Now some light. O, he lights too. He's ta'en. And, hark! they shout for joy.
Shout

lines.speaker: cassius
lines.text: Come down, behold no more. O, coward that I am, to live so long, To see my best friend ta'en before my face! Come hither, sirrah: In Parthia did I take thee prisoner; And then I swore thee, saving of thy life, That whatsoever I did bid thee do, Thou shouldst attempt it. Come now, keep thine oath; Now be a freeman: and with this good sword, That ran through Caesar's bowels, search this bosom. Stand not to answer: here, take thou the hilts; And, when my face is cover'd, as 'tis now, Guide thou the sword. Caesar, thou art revenged, Even with the sword that kill'd thee.
PINDARUS descends
PINDARUS stabs him
Dies

lines.speaker: pindarus
lines.text: So, I am free; yet would not so have been, Durst I have done my will. O Cassius, Far from this country Pindarus shall run, Where never Roman shall take note of him.
Exit
Re-enter TITINIUS with MESSALA

lines.speaker: messala
lines.text: It is but change, Titinius; for Octavius Is overthrown by noble Brutus' power, As Cassius' legions are by Antony.

lines.speaker: titinius
lines.text: These tidings will well comfort Cassius.

lines.speaker: messala
lines.text: Where did you leave him?

lines.speaker: titinius
lines.text: All disconsolate, With Pindarus his bondman, on this hill.

lines.speaker: messala
lines.text: Is not that he t hat lies upon the ground?

lines.speaker: titinius
lines.text: He lies not like the living. O my heart!

lines.speaker: messala
lines.text: Is not that he?

lines.speaker: titinius
lines.text: No, this was he, Messala, But Cassius is no more. O setting sun, As in thy red rays thou dost sink to-night, So in his red blood Cassius' day is set; The sun of Rome is set! Our day is gone; Clouds, dews, and dangers come; our deeds are done! Mistrust of my success hath done this deed.

lines.speaker: messala
lines.text: Mistrust of good success hath done this deed. O hateful error, melancholy's child, Why dost thou show to the apt thoughts of men The things that are not? O error, soon conceived, Thou never comest unto a happy birth, But kill'st the mother that engender'd thee!

lines.speaker: titinius
lines.text: What, Pindarus! where art thou, Pindarus?

lines.speaker: messala
lines.text: Seek him, Titinius, whilst I go to meet The noble Brutus, thrusting this report Into his ears; I may say, thrusting it; For piercing steel and darts envenomed Shall be as welcome to the ears of Brutus As tidings of this sight.

lines.speaker: titinius
lines.text: Hie you, Messala, And I will seek for Pindarus the while. Why didst thou send me forth, brave Cassius? Did I not meet thy friends? and did not they Put on my brows this wreath of victory, And bid me give it thee? Didst thou not hear their shouts? Alas, thou hast misconstrued every thing! But, hold thee, take this garland on thy brow; Thy Brutus bid me give it thee, and I Will do his bidding. Brutus, come apace, And see how I regarded Caius Cassius. By your leave, gods:--this is a Roman's part Come, Cassius' sword, and find Titinius' heart.
Exit MESSALA
Kills himself
Alarum. Re-enter MESSALA, with BRUTUS, CATO, STRATO, VOLUMNIUS, and LUCILIUS

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Where, where, Messala, doth his body lie?

lines.speaker: messala
lines.text: Lo, yonder, and Titinius mourning it.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Titinius' face is upward.

lines.speaker: cato
lines.text: He is slain.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: O Julius Caesar, thou art mighty yet! Thy spirit walks abroad and turns our swords In our own proper entrails.
Low alarums

lines.speaker: cato
lines.text: Brave Titinius! Look, whether he have not crown'd dead Cassius!

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Are yet two Romans living such as these? The last of all the Romans, fare thee well! It is impossible that ever Rome Should breed thy fellow. Friends, I owe more tears To this dead man than you shall see me pay. I shall find time, Cassius, I shall find time. Come, therefore, and to Thasos send his body: His funerals shall not be in our camp, Lest it discomfort us. Lucilius, come; And come, young Cato; let us to the field. Labeo and Flavius, set our battles on: 'Tis three o'clock; and, Romans, yet ere night We shall try fortune in a second fight. Yet, countrymen, O, yet hold up your heads!
Exeunt
